thread.title_full: Domino's Pizza is far more valuable a digital company than any so-called tech 'unicorn'

title: Domino's Pizza is far more valuable a digital company than any so-called tech 'unicorn'
text:
0.00 
The pizza delivery firm has embraced technology - to the benefit of shareholders 
Barely a day goes by without a technology company you probably haven’t heard of and probably won’t hear of again declaring that it has become the next 'unicorn.’ 
The 'unicorn’ mantle was first used by venture capitalists to describe those privately owned companies that have risen to a valuation of $1bn (£650m) or more, and has since become the phrase du jour for all those who oscillate around tech circles. 
A very subjective term, given such valuations are based on private fundraisings driven by a relatively small band of investors with little public visibility, it has become the go-to phrase in a tech world desperate to show that it’s more than just Google and Apple (LSE: 0R2V.L - news ) . 
From well-known 'unicorns’ such as Uber and Spotify, to the less well known Theranos and Zenefits (no, me neither) the technology world and those who feed off it have never been keener to promote the idea that theirs is a sector which is booming. 
Just look at the headlines. “Billion-dollar tech start-ups on the increase in Europe” proclaimed one newspaper at the start of the summer. “Europe incubates tech’s new billion-dollar babies,” read another. 
And if the unicorn mantra is to be believed and that, is a big if - it is a sector that is booming in the UK. 
A recent survey by corporate finance advisers GP Bullhound showed that the UK has the largest number of unicorns than any other country. 
Some will point to this as a sign that the push to create a technology hub in the east of London has worked; and that finally, years of investment are beginning to bear fruit. 
Others however would question whether the hype around such companies is simply the latest sign of a valuation bubble in the technology market with doe-eyed investors, desperate to place their cash in growth stocks, ramping up the value of companies which on a public market would be worth far less. 
But for all this chatter around unicorns lord, there’s even a phrase decacorns - for companies with a valuation of $10bn or more there are real questions to be asked. 
Do these companies have a long term future? Will they deliver any profits? And will they actually employ any staff, and thereby contribute to the economy in which they exist, save the handful of engineers who founded them? 
But amidst such questions around these start-ups, and this constant angst about whether the UK will ever deliver a technology champion, there is one British technology-focused company which is delivering real profits and substantial shareholder growth. 
The only problem is that rather than delivering fuel cells or multi-player video games, it delivers pizzas. 
For Domino’s Pizza Group, the FTSE 250 constituent, is growing swiftly on the back of its substantial investment in technology. 
In fact, based on the rather ridiculous unicorn definition, it is 2.6 unicorns, given its market capitalisation of £1.7bn equates to $2.6bn. 
Fictional horse-like horned mammals aside, however, the Domino’s Pizza story is one of digital investment benefitting shareholders to an increasing degree. 
One need only look at Domino’s share price graph to see that benefit. Seven years ago, in October 2008, its shares were languishing around the 166.5p mark. 
On Wednesday, its shares closed at £10.02 ending above £10 for the first time - having risen 112p on the day following a profit upgrade. 
Its third quarter trading statement reflected just how much that digital investment is paying off. 
Like-for-like sales in the three months to September 27 rose 14.9pc in the UK, leading the company to say it would beat previous 2015 profit expectations and prompting analysts to increase earnings expectations by 5- 6pc for this year. 
The reason for that upgrade? Digital investment. It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) is easy to see Domino’s as an old economy business, which is involved in simply making pizzas in small retail units, and delivering them to customers’ homes. 
But that would be an archane and outdated view of a company which is much changed. 
Yes, it still delivers pizzas from those same confined spaces but it does so in an increasingly digital way. 
Although the company won’t disclose how much it has spent on digital investment other than to say it doubled its technology investment this year compared to last year and next year will increase it by a further 75pc - the results speak for themselves. 
Nearly 80pc of its orders are now made online, compared to less than 30pc just five years ago. 
And although Domino’s only took its first order on a mobile device five years ago, some two-thirds of its digital orders are now made on a smart phone or a tablet. 
The efficiencies digital orders bring to a business whose main cost is staff is significant. 
Although Domino’s doesn’t own any of its UK stores they are all franchised those costs are meaningful to its franchisees, who have been important in suggesting key upgrades to Domino’s mobile app. 
The next step, according to chief executive David Wild, is to deliver an app which allows for one-click ordering, which could be as early as next year, and to try and fine tune payment options to allow for credit card details to be saved. 
The company uses social networks such as Twitter (Xetra: A1W6XZ - news ) to entice customers 
He argues that while many consumer facing businesses are still on a path to digital transformation, Domino’s is already thinking like a business that is digital. 
Out of 230 head office staff, some 85 are software engineers and technologists. From a current base of 860 stores, Wild think there’s potential for 1,200 across the UK, meaning considerable room for growth. 
Yes the company has had its fair share of problems in Germany, which it’s now working on stabilising, but unlike many technology-focused companies it’s throwing off cash (it had net cash of £19.2m at the end of June) and is due to generate pre-tax profits of approximately £69m this year. 
Too much time is spent by commentators and civil servants wondering why the UK doesn’t have any real technology champions it can shout about. 
Forget the unicorns. This is a much revolutionised company which owes it increasing success to its understanding of the digital revolution and investing to make sure it stays at the forefront of those changes. 
In a few years, Domino’s Pizza Group could be knocking on the door of the FTSE 100. And when it does, it will be technology that has got it there. 
james.quinn@telegraph.co.uk
